text: 1961 cadillac from tailfin Cadillacs 23
tonne suvs luxury vehicles have always
pushed the limits of size and mass but
now car makers are unveiling luxury and
smaller packages i'm lawrence ulrich for
the new york times at this year's New
York Auto Show opening friday the Audi
a3 is part of a wave of small yet deluxe
cars coming to showrooms in America now
the Audi like a lot of these half-pint
luxury model starts for around thirty
thousand dollars but it still offers
that designer badge and status along
with many of the features you might
expect in a larger more expensive luxury
car leather navigation Wi-Fi connection
rocking Bang & Olufsen audio system even
frugal plug-in hybrid and diesel models
if you look at Audi you know nearly
fifty percent of our sales come from Gen
X and Gen Y and what we see is they are
looking for appropriately sized cars
with high design and high technology so
that's why we see a good fit here in
past decades consumers rejected compact
luxury cars that seemed more like
designer knock-offs the Mercedes 190 a
low budget luxury sedan was dismissed as
the poor man's Mercedes but the BMW
designed Mini Cooper helped change
perceptions of what a small car could be
and how much people would pay for one
and in this post recession ERA american
consumers seemed to appreciate that
small doesn't mean cheap slow or frumpy
this new and fast-growing class of
downsized luxury cars includes
crossovers like the lincoln MKC Buicks
encore the BMW x1 as well as mercedes
new CLA sedan and it's electric be class
while american consumers are looking to
save money on gas new environmental
regulations are also driving the shift
to smaller luxury cars the consequences
of the co2 regulations the EPA
regulations that will take us to 54 and
a half miles per gallon by 2025 are
going to be dramatic it's going to have
a dramatic impact on our overall
portfolio and that's going to mean
smaller engine displacements more
efficiency start/stop solutions to
alternative drive trains like full
electrics it's just difficult right now
when gas hangs around three dot fifty
cents a gallon there's not this natural
demand pull so it's more of a government
regulation pushed that we're trying to
navigate it's tricky while some
Americans will always prefer tradition
whether it's vintage or modern these
smaller more affordable luxury cars are
poised to be the fastest growing part of
the luxury market
